turn.text: --Your Honor, they were not denied this opportunity at trial to introduce the evidence with respect to the non-railroad employment, and you can see that because they actually did do some cross-examination, they did try to introduce the evidence of three months, they did try to refer to the other workplaces, they could have tried to introduce more evidence.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, why was that relevant if there's joint liability?

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: Well, we thought it was irrelevant, Your Honor, but they were clearly thinking about the possibility of requesting an apportionment instruction, but the fact is, they never laid out a reasonable basis.
If you look at the memorandum--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Oh, but they did request an instruction, didn't they?

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: --They did request the instruction, but--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So the point was preserved.

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: --Right, but the trial court was correct in denying the instruction because they had not met their burden of proffering a reasonable basis for apportionment, and in the absence of that evidentiary basis, the trial court was absolutely correct in denying it.
This was a jury verdict, Your Honor, this was reached.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Oh, but that theory, then, is that several liability would have been appropriate if the evidence were sufficient?

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: Well, no, Your Honor.
Our threshold argument is that it would not... asbestosis, this is a classic individual injury.
There are many courts who have talked about this, and they said, well, in theory, asbestosis is dose-related.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: With respect, Mr. Lazarus, isn't your... the bottom line in this argument that this is simply not an issue in this case, because they didn't provide a basis?

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: Yes, that's absolutely right.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So you're saying, forget it.

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: That's right.
They had the burden and they simply didn't meet their burden.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And they say you had the burden.

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: Well, but it's quite--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It seems to me that argument goes to the weight of the evidence they offered, rather than to the... your legal position.
I may be missing something.

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, no, they have to as a matter of law, right, proffer some kind, and here there's absolutely nothing--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but they did proffer... if I remember it, they did proffer evidence as to the time that these people worked in other areas where they were exposed to asbestos, didn't they?

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: --There was some evidence--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But you're saying that's not enough.

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: --There's some evidence as to that, but in fact if you can look to their instruction they don't even say what... that time is the relevant factor, and I think the evidence at trial shows that time is not even close to establishing what the dose relationship would be.
This is very complicated.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But aren't you really saying that unless there's an abuse of discretion on the part of the trial judge in refusing to send this to the jury, based on what you've just described, insufficiency of evidence on their part, that it's not in the case for us?

turn.speaker: richard_j_lazarus
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Lazarus
turn.text: That's absolutely right, Your Honor.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Lazarus.
Mr. Phillips, you have two minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
I want to be absolutely clear about the apportionment in this case.
We put in an instruction on apportionment based on a reasonable basis following Justice Kennedy's analysis of the law, which says if there's a reasonable basis to apportion, you do that.
The trial judge did not reject that on the basis of insufficient evidence.
What he said at page 179, volume 9 of the transcript is, if you've got a joint tort-feasor, that tort-feasor is liable for all of the injuries.
He said it as a matter of law.
It's joint and several liability.
There is no apportionment.
That's the ruling we challenged.
That's the legal issue before this Court.
The second question, then, with your leave, is to--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but should we adopt your position if it's as difficult to show this separate causation as your brother argues?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, Dean Prosser said from day one it's always going to be difficult to apportion, but that's no reason not to have the jury undertake to apportion.
There are lots of decisions that juries make that are very hard to make, but the better rule is to apportion, because that's the fair outcome that will arise in these cases.

With respect to the fear of cancer damages, the key to this case, it seems to me, is just how big a gatekeeper function the fact of asbestosis can be, and my... the argument is, asbestosis is extraordinarily easy to diagnose.
There are currently 5,500 cases under FELA in West Virginia.
Every single one of them involves a claim of asbestosis.
Every single one of them will be supported by an expert.
What you get is, that's not a gatekeeper.
Those cases are going to come in, and then you're going to have exactly the kinds of evidence you had in this case, I'm afraid of cancer, give me whatever you think is the right number.
That is the essence of unpredictable and unlimited damages.
This Court declined to allow that under FELA in Buckley.
It should decline to allow that under FELA in this case as well.
If there are no questions, I'll reserve--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Phillips.
The case is submitted.
